title: £10 million fund announced to regenerate Welsh town centres

text:
Neath Port Talbot will receive £1 million in loan funding Credit: PA A £10 million fund to help bring empty, underused sites and shops in town centres back into use has been announced.
The money is the third phase of a new Welsh Government loan fund, which aims to redevelop properties in town centres as shops, homes and leisure facilities.
The money will support town centre regeneration in twelve areas of Wales.
The Cabinet Secretary for Communities and Children, Carl Sargeant, who launched the latest allocation to the fund, says it's a chance to support investment in local economies.
Wrexham will receive a loan amount of £1 million for the acquisition and redevelopment of key buildings Credit: ITV Cymru Wales This funding will help Local Authorities regenerate their town centres by helping them find sustainable uses for empty sites and premises such as affordable town centre homes or tourist and leisure attractions.
As well as making town centres more attractive places to live this loan scheme will help encourage investment into these areas as well as support the local economy.
– Carl Sargeant AM, Communities and Children Secretary The following local authorities have been allocated loan funding:
Denbighshire Newport Neath Port Talbot Cardiff Pembrokeshire Wrexham Conwy Powys Gwynedd Rhondda Cynon Taff Ceredigion Anglesey Ceredigion will receive a loan amount of £500,000 for the town of Aberystwyth Credit: ITV Cymru Wales The loan amounts vary from a quarter of a million allocated for Anglesey, up to a million for Cardiff, Denbighshire, Neath Port Talbot, Pembrokeshire, Powys and Wrexham.
The money is earmarked for a number of projects across the country.
